preface.title: Preface
preface.para: DocBook is a XML format to write documentation mostly for hard- and software, but is not limited to this domain. With the help of the DocBook XSL stylesheets, text can be published into different target formats.

Although there are helpful and valuable documentation like the DocBook The Definitive Guide from Norman Walsh and Bob Stayton 's DocBook XSL book, until now nobody wrote a book that combines the best of both worlds. My book is intented to be such a book. However, it does not want to replace the prior mentioned de facto standards. It aims for enhancing the world of DocBook.

My book is a collection of problem-and-solution scenarios written in a cookbook style. It is the nature of such a topic that there might be some overlap with the previous books above. However, I think, it is naturally and we always benefit from different opinions and sights.

The scenarios are mostly based on my own experiences with DocBook and the DocBook XSL stylesheets. However, it also includes questions and answers from the DocBook mailinglists, or interesting things that I have found from different Web sites. When I was inspired from other authors, I have included their names into it.
As I have learned a lot from the masters of DocBook, it is time to give something back. This book is written under a Creative Commons license. I hope the DocBook community will find it useful.

section.title: Audience
section.para: You should know at least DocBook, have heard (and even better worked!) with CSS and XSLT. This book does not attempt to teach you DocBook, XSLT, CSS, XSL-FO, or any other related technology.
